subtitle: “If, in some cataclysm, all of scientific knowledge were to be destroyed, and only one
sentence passed on to the next generations of creatures, what statement would contain
the most information in the fewest words?
I believe it is the atomic hypothesis (or the atomic fact, or whatever you wish to call it)
that all things are made of atoms.”
The ship rattles as it stretches out into
the void, beginning the adventure of a lifetime.
The nervous crew are off on an epic journey
to visit their home world's only natural satellite. Though similar in concept to the journey undertaken
by the Apollo astronauts when they left Earth for the Moon - this voyage is very different.
When Armstrong and Aldrin headed for history on the lunar surface, they needed only to
travel a distance equal to the width of thirty Earths.
Our intrepid travellers must cover a distance equal to more than 63,000 times the diameter
of their home world. Compared to the crew´s destination though,
the Moon is a celestial snail. It crawls around the Earth once a month at a speed of 1000
metres per second. That may sound fast, but this satellite is whipping around at over
two million metres per second or just under one per cent the speed of light. It's moving
so quickly that it completes 6.5 quadrillion orbits each and every second.
For it is no moon.
And this is no solar system.
Our travellers are not exploring the astronomical realm, but the atomic one.
They are brave atomonauts, adrift inside the hydrogen atom. Departing from the solitary
proton at its centre, they are in search of the lone electron that encircles it.
But their mission is a lot harder than it first appears. The electron only orbits the
proton like a moon orbits a planet in the simplified Bohr model of the atom, named after
the Danish physicist Niels Bohr. Modern quantum physics says that we can never know for certain
where the electron actually is – we can only say where it's most likely to be. The
blur of all its possible paths creates a cloud around the nucleus. Our atomonauts could therefore
never land at their destination - only float into the fog of possibility.
These atoms are the universe's lego bricks. Vast galaxies swirl in the void and distant
stars keep vigil over the night, but they are all built out of atoms. As we all are.
Indeed, there's an entire cosmos inside you. The number of atoms in your body alone exceeds
the total number of stars in the entire observable universe. Even if you started counting them
at a rate of a billion a second, it would still take you far longer than the current
age of the universe to complete the task. And as we have seen - even within those atoms
themselves, there are entire complex systems to explore.
And yet… at the very beginning of time the number of atoms in the universe was precisely
zero. Not a single atom in the entirety of the cosmos.
So how did we end up here? Where did the very first atom come from?
And just why is everything made of atoms?
The earth weighs about 6.58 billion trillion
tons, and about 1.85 billion billion of that is carbon.
The climate can sometimes feels like an impossibly big problem for one person to try and solve.
And yet that is where Wren comes in, our sponsor today.
Wren is a website where you can calculate your carbon footprint, then offset it by funding
a mix of carbon reduction projects like tree planting, mineral weathering and rainforest
protection. By answering a few simple questions about
your lifestyle you can find out your carbon footprint, and how to reduce it - and then
you can actually offset what you have left over.
You receive regular updates on what you support - one particularly impressive project is Biochar
in California - which prevents wildfires by removing dead and flammable trees, then turning
the biomass into biochar, thus stopping it from ending up in the atmosphere. A cutting
edge way to tackle the climate. So, offset your carbon footprint on Wren.
The first 100 people who sign up using the link in the
description, will have 10 extra trees planted in their name.
Thanks to Wren for supporting educational content on youtube.
A wicked wind howls across the Black Sea. Waves swell and crash as the previously mirror
smooth water is tossed and churned. Marooned on a kayak amid this maelstrom is
a pair of newly-weds.
They are refugees, fleeing Ukraine to escape
from the Russian regime. Yet this is not a twenty-first century story.
The year is 1932 and the couple stranded in the tumult are the physicist George Gamow
and his wife Lyubov, who he affectionately calls Rho after the Greek letter.
What could drive this young couple to risk their lives on such a perilous voyage?
The early 1930s witnessed a big shift in the way the Soviets treated their scientists and
intellectual ideas and foreign trips were increasingly tightly policed. Gamow wants
to present his research at a large scientific conference in Rome, but needs a new passport.
His application is constantly kicked into the long grass by bureaucrats in Leningrad
who promise progress, but instead deliberately run down the clock. He never goes to the Italian
capital. Yet his endless visits to the passport office
have one significant upside: it is there that he meets Rho. They marry soon after and within
a year the newly-weds agree to flee. They pore over maps looking for the surest means
of escape from the Soviet Union. And so they settle on the Black Sea, leaving
Gamow's birthplace of Odessa to head for Turkey. Gamow still has a Danish motorcycle licence
from his days collaborating with the physicist Niels Bohr in Copenhagen, and so the plan
is to wash up on a Turkish beach, pretend to be Danish and ask to be taken to the Danish
embassy in Istanbul. Their journey couldn't have started better.
The water is calm and the breeze is gentle. But when they awake before sunrise the second
day the weather is already turning. By the evening, the situation intensifies and soon
becomes perilous. By the time the storm abates they are exhausted to the point of hallucination.
Drifting alone on the open water, strong winds buffet the boat all the way back to Crimea.
Despite this setback, eventually Gamow and Rho do escape. They secure passage to a scientific
conference in Belgium and after the conference, Marie Curie helps the couple extend their
stay in Western Europe. Never to return to the Soviet Union, they finally headed to the
United States in early 1934. This entire odyssey has unfolded before Gamow's
thirtieth birthday. Six years later, Gamow is granted American
citizenship. Free from the shackles of oppression, he is now able to continue his work.
And it is this work that would turn out to be pivotal in our understanding of physics
- for it would change the way we think about the history of the universe forever.
In 1929, three years before Gamow's exploits on the Black Sea, the American astronomer
Edwin Hubble had shocked the astronomical establishment with evidence that the universe
is expanding. If the universe is growing day by day then it was smaller yesterday and smaller
still a week ago. Keep rewinding the clock and there was a time when every part of the
modern universe was concentrated down into an incredibly small space before it expanded
outwards. The Big Bang. Except that it wasn't such a new idea to Gamow.
The Russian physicist Alexander Friedmann had already predicted the universe's expansion
back in 1925 and the pair had lengthy discussions about it during Gamow's time in Leningrad.
Gamow spent much of his early time in America working on something else – the ultimate
power source of stars. Yet the focus of his attention was shifting. In October 1945, Gamow
writes a letter to his old friend Niels Bohr to mark the Dane's 60th birthday.
The letter reveals that Gamow was starting to apply his work on the internal mechanics
of stars to the origin of matter in the early universe immediately after the Big Bang.
Up until this point cosmologists had assumed that the early universe was dominated by matter,
the stuff that all visible structure is made of, from stars and planets to galaxies and
galaxy clusters. Yet Gamow began to suspect otherwise. History wavers on who truly deserves
the credit, but it could have been Gamow's student Ralph Alpher. In his doctoral dissertation
Alpher claimed that the early universe wasn't dominated by matter, but by electromagnetic
radiation. This electromagnetic radiation would supposedly dominate the early universe
for a full fifty thousand years after the Big Bang.
Physicists have another word for electromagnetic radiation: light. We may use that word for
the light our eyes can see, but there's more to it than that.
Just as there are frequencies of sound too low or high for our ears to hear, there are
frequencies of light too low or high for us to see.
When a physicist uses the word light they mean the radiation that spans the full range
of these frequencies, from gamma-rays and X-rays at the high frequency end to microwaves
and radio waves at the other. When you use a microwave to heat your dinner, you're actually
cooking the food using low-frequency light. And so light and matter were trapped together
in the nascent universe. After 100,000 seconds of expansion, the entire universe was still
denser than the air you're breathing right now - and continued for thousands of years
to be dense enough for sound waves to travel through.
Sound waves of such low frequency that they'd need to be squashed by 100 septillion times
– that's 1 followed by 26 zeroes – just to push them into the range of human hearing
- something that in 2013 John G Cramer at Washington University used data from the early
universe to reproduce:
Cosmologists call these sound waves baryon
acoustic oscillations and they can still be detected today using facilities such as the
Sloan Digital Sky Survey. As the universe kept expanding it continued to stretch out
these sound waves, shifting them to ever lower frequencies.
But then there came a point when everything changed.
It is one of the most important events in the entire history of the universe – and
it was predicted by none other than Alpher and Gamow. It is called recombination and
it also opened the floodgates for the first light to come streaming out into the early
universe. But what recombined exactly?
And what does this first light have to do with the first atom?
The feeling of claustrophobia rises by the second. You're trapped.
Whichever way you turn just leads to a blocked path.
Have you seen these walls before? Did you turn right or left at this junction earlier?
No matter how hard you try, you just can't figure out how to escape.
And that is not surprising. Because there is no escape.
You are trapped in an impenetrable maze. This series of never-ending dead-ends is exactly
what light encountered after the Big Bang. Everywhere light tried to go it bumped into
insurmountable obstacles in the form of sub-atomic particles. And yet the universe didn't begin
as such a labyrinth. In the very beginning there was none of this matter to get in the
way. For the faintest sliver of a second, just after its birth, it was free.
But very quickly light turned into its own captor, snapping the shackles shut on itself.
This happened because light leads a double life. Like the vampires and werewolves of
myth and folklore it can shape-shift into something else: matter. Light is a form of
energy, and energy and matter are two sides of the same cosmic coin. They are completely
interchangeable. And the more energetic the light, the higher the likelihood it will change
into matter. Within a trillionth of a second after the
Big Bang some of the universe's energy is converted into particles of matter that start
popping into existence, flooding the universe with fundamental particles - everything needed
to build atoms, including electrons. Yet we'll still have to wait hundreds of thousands of
years for these particles to actually coalesce into the first atom.
We may already have electrons, but to make a hydrogen atom, like the one explored by
our atomonauts, we also need a proton. Unlike electrons, they are built out of something
else: quarks – fundamental particles that also appeared during light's partial metamorphosis
into matter. Quarks come in a menu of different flavours,
but the most important ones for our story of atom formation are the up quark and the
down quark. Up quarks carry a positive charge and down quarks a negative charge. A proton
is made of two up quarks and one down quark, giving a proton an overall positive charge.
Yet these quarks are not natural bedfellows. Electric charges act like the poles of a magnet
– opposites attract, but like charges repel one another. How can two positively charged
up quarks happily sit side by side inside a proton?
The solution to this puzzle lies with forces, the glue needed to stick the first atom together.
Physicists know of four fundamental forces in the universe. Two are familiar to us: gravity
and electromagnetism. Light is an electromagnetic wave and it is electromagnetism that repels
like magnets and quarks from one another. Down in the atomic world, two less familiar
forces are at a play. The weak nuclear force governs radioactivity, but it's the strong
nuclear force that really dominates here. It is one duodecillion times stronger than
gravity. That's ten followed by thirty-eight zeroes – significantly more zeroes than
there are stars in the entire observable universe. The strong nuclear force is also one hundred
times stronger than the electromagnetic force. So two quarks with the same charge may want
to push away from one another, but the strong nuclear force can override this electromagnetic
instinct and keep them tied together. There is a catch, though.
The strong nuclear force may be the king of the forces, but the kingdom it governs is
tiny. It only has dominion over the most minute of distances: about a trillionth of a millimetre.
Initially energies are too high for quarks to bind together through the strong force.
When the quarks first formed, the temperature of the universe was over one quadrillion degrees.
Though they pass very close to each other, the quarks collide with such high energy that
they cannot stick. But the new universe is expanding all the
time. It cools as it grows and particles within it slow down. After the first millionth of
a second the temperature drops to a mere one trillion degrees and the first protons are
able to form. Neutrons form too, the other kind of particle you'll find in an atomic
nucleus. They are made of one up quark and two down quarks.
Simple enough, you might think. But again, as with Bohr´s model of the atom,
neutrons and protons are not quite that straightforward.
Indeed, the more physicists learn about the proton, the more downright weird it gets.
To quote Mike Williams, physicist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology: “This is the most complicated thing that
you could possibly imagine,” For one thing, together the three quarks – known
as valence quarks - actually make up just one per cent of the proton's mass. The rest
is taken up by particles called gluons. They are the particles that carry the strong nuclear
force. It's by exchanging gluons that the trio of valence quarks are able to bind together
into a proton. Yet it gets a lot stranger. Occasionally gluons
pick up enough energy that they can do some shape-shifting of their own, turning into
a quark and its antimatter equivalent the anti-quark. These so-called “sea quarks”
then quickly recombine back into a gluon. So at any one time a proton is really a blur
of valence quarks, gluons and sea quarks. We still don't understand all the details
and experiments like the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider in New York are helping physicists
probe deeper inside the proton. What we do know is that gluons and sea quarks
make up 99 percent of the proton's mass. Because they aren't permanent, physicists refer to
the sea quarks as virtual particles. This means that the mass of the proton – the
particle you'll find at the centre of every atom in the universe – mostly comes from
an infinity of sea quarks that don't actually exist.
From top and bottom, strange to charm, a whole range of quarks can be found as sea quarks,
popping in and out of existence for just short enough periods to not break conservation of
energy. A recent experiment at the University of Milan
has even shown that sometimes charm quarks actually appear at lower energies.
And most bizarrely, charm quarks have almost 1 and a half times the mass of the entire
proton - the low probability of this happening meaning that their full mass isn´t added
to the proton itself. The quantum world of the very small is a counterintuitive place.
Returning to the universe's timeline - now that we have protons and neutrons, the next
stop on our journey to the first atom comes as the universe continues to cool and expand,
meaning the protons and neutrons lose speed. And it is here that George Gamow re-enters
our story. In 1948 he has a letter published in the scientific
journal Physical Review Letters. It runs to no more than a page, but its length belies
the magnitude of its insights. The paper suggests that within a handful of
minutes of the Big Bang the universe cooled to a billion degrees, enough to allow the
strong nuclear force to stick a proton to a neutron. This proton-neutron pair is known
as a deuteron and it's the gateway to a whole new way of building structure in the infant
universe. Stars like the Sun generate vast amounts of
light by churning hydrogen into helium through a process called nuclear fusion. Slightly
less helium comes out than the amount of hydrogen that goes in and the difference is converted
into sunshine as mass turns back into energy. Along with Ralph Alpher, Gamow was the first
to figure out the series of steps by which fusion turns hydrogen into helium - and deuterons
played a crucial role - for when a deuteron combines with a proton it makes the nucleus
of a helium-3 atom. Then when two helium-3 nuclei fuse they make the nucleus of a helium-4
atom, and two extra neutrons. In the modern universe these reactions can only unfold in
places with extremes of temperature and pressure like the cores of stars.
But similar temperatures were present universe wide soon after the Big Bang, though not for
long. There was only an incredibly short window of opportunity for fusion to take place. The
temperature had to be cool enough for deuterons to form in the first place, but still hot
enough to fuse everything else together. And that window opened less than a second
after the Big Bang and slammed about twenty minutes later when the temperature of the
universe cooled. A roughly twenty minute period in which about a quarter of the universe's
mass of hydrogen nuclei turned into helium nuclei.
And so we have a universe that's still just 20 minutes old, sprinkled with twelve hydrogen
nuclei for every one helium nucleus and a billion particles of light for every nucleus.
Incredible progress in just over a quarter of an hour.
But we still don't have the first atom. For that we need to bind electrons in orbit
around these nuclei. And that would take a very long time indeed.
Electrons are negatively charged and protons make atomic nuclei positively charged. Opposites
attract and so the electromagnetic force can snare a passing electron and trap it in orbit
around the nucleus. But the electromagnetic force is one hundred
times weaker than the strong nuclear force - so the universe has to cool all the way
down to just 4000 degrees in order for the particles to slow down enough for the electromagnetic
force to do its thing. It will take 380,000 years of expansion after
the Big Bang until the universe reaches this point.
Then, finally, the first atom forms. But as with the bizarre components of its
nucleus, adding electrons certainly doesn´t make things any less complicated.
Electrons were discovered towards the end of the 19th century, yet time has only burnished
their enigma. At almost two thousand times lighter than a proton, an electron is generally
thought to be a single point with no shape or internal structure - truly fundamental,
like quarks. They don't orbit the nucleus like planets
around the Sun, either. Quantum physics tells us that it is impossible to know both the
position and speed of an electron with perfect accuracy. At any one time an electron isn't
in one spot around the nucleus - it simultaneously occupies every possible spot. A single electron
envelops the nucleus like a fog and we can only talk about where it is most likely to
be. Electrons, as with all other fundamental particles,
also have a curious property called 'spin'. They are deflected by magnetic fields as if
they were rotating balls of charge. This rotation is counterintuitive. If you
spin around 360 degrees – in other words rotate through a full circle – then you'd
return to where you started. You're a spin 1 entity. But electrons are spin ½ entities
– they have to be rotated through 720 degrees to return to where they started. Except that
electrons aren't actually spinning at all – quantum physics forbids it. Though it
is useful to think of them as spinning, they can't be.
And so everywhere we look, the inside of an atom is like a giant hall of mirrors. Deception,
illusion and subterfuge accompany each of our endeavours to understand it - a bizarre
quantum realm that runs counter to common sense, wrapped up in mysteries that we are
very far from unravelling. But what we do know is that the formation
of the first atoms some 380,000 after the Big Bang set light free.
Photons of light now have a way out of the previously impenetrable maze that they had
inflicted upon themselves. With electrons suddenly sucked into orbits
around atomic nuclei, there is an abrupt increase in the space between matter. Light can travel
without whacking into anything, and off it goes at 299 792 458 m / s.
In 1948 Ralph Alpher and Robert Herman built on this work and predicted that this first
light to flood out in the universe hundreds of millennia after the Big Bang should still
be visible today. And finding it would be the equivalent of
a smoking gun, a hard-to-argue-with proof that the universe really did begin with a
hot Big Bang. Unfortunately, no-one took much notice and
the idea was largely forgotten about for a decade and a half.
Until...
A fresh-faced Robert Dicke stands on the roof
of the Radiation Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, holding a device
of his own making aloft. Dicke joined MIT under a cloak of secrecy
in September 1941 having only just completed his PhD at the age of 25. The Second World
War has been raging for two years, and although the United States remains neutral, it is starting
to make preparations for joining the fray. They were right to. Within weeks of Dicke
starting at MIT, the Japanese attack Pearl Harbour and the United States enters the war
the very next day. Dicke is a keen inventor with a real skill
for electronics. It's in the blood – his father was a patent attorney and Dicke Jr
would go on to file over 50 patents in his lifetime, for devices from clothes dryers
to lasers. But at MIT Dicke is working on radar.
The term radar - an acronym for RAdio Detection And Ranging – was coined by the US Navy
just the year before. By sending out short pulses of radio waves, you can detect objects
like enemy aircraft when they reflect those radio waves back to you. Except that radar
was initially a pretty blunt instrument. Radio waves are a form of light, part of the
electromagnetic spectrum. They have the longest wavelength of any light – the distance over
which the wave repeats itself. Radar has been around since the 1930s, but Dicke is working
on a big improvement: using microwaves instead. Microwaves have a shorter wavelength than
radio waves, meaning your radar picture will show greater detail. Dicke invents a new receiver
to pick up these reflected microwaves, now called the Dicke radiometer.
Yet the curious child within him can't help but look even further up, beyond the bombers
and the dogfighters, to space. Dicke wonders whether any microwaves are coming from the
cosmos. And so here he is, on the roof of the Radiation
Laboratory of MIT, pointing his radiometer to the sky.
It's an idea he would return to over a decade later at Princeton as part of one of the most
important insights in 20th century cosmology. Ultimately it would validate our story of
the origin of the very first atoms. As with many of us, Dicke finds the idea of
the Big Bang a little conceptually troubling. How can something come from nothing is perhaps
the most asked question about the universe's origin. So Dicke explores the idea of cyclical
universes - an expanding universe that slows, stops and shrinks, collapsing back in on itself
in a Big Crunch, only to explode outwards again in another Big Bang.
A collapsing universe would get exceptionally hot as matter crushed down on itself. Electrons
would get ripped away from protons as the universe returned to a sea of sub-atomic shrapnel.
Dicke dubs this mega-hot maelstrom a “fireball”. The ensuing bounce and expansion would cool
the fireball back down and allow atoms to reform – and this is where the name “recombination”
originates. In this theory the atoms truly would recombine.
By thinking this scenario through, Dicke, like Gamow over a decade earlier, hits upon
the notion that there should be relic radiation left over from this super-hot stage and that
it would still be visible today. He calls it fireball radiation. It's the same radiation
from recombination that Gamow and his colleagues predicted back in 1948, although Dicke is
initially unaware of their work. Dicke reasons that this fireball radiation should now be
in the microwave part of the electromagnetic spectrum - the very part he has spent two
decades working on. Of course initially the leftover light from
the Big Bang would have been in the visible part of the spectrum. Had anyone been around
to see it, it would have glowed yellow-orange. But the universe has continued to expand ever
since the light was released 13.42 billion years ago. That expansion has stretched the
space between everything, also redshifting any waves of electromagnetic radiation travelling
through that space. Dicke calculates that his fireball radiation
would have been stretched right out through the infra-red and into the microwave spectrum.
And so he resolves to find it with his eponymous radiometer and begins to plan an observation
run that would start in the mid-1960s. But something strange happens before he has
a chance to finish his work. Forty five minutes drive away in Holmdel,
New Jersey, two radio astronomers are attempting a different kind of experiment. Their names
are Arno Penzias and Robert Wilson. Like Gamow before him, Penzias fled European totalitarianism
– a child evacuee from 1930s Germany.
Penzias and Wilson are using the giant six
metre Holmdel Horn Antenna, part of Bell Telephone Laboratories, to listen out for radio waves
reflected off orbiting satellites. The signals they are looking for are faint
– to hear them they must first get rid of any other interference. They eliminate local
radar and radio transmission and even remove interference from the receiver itself by cooling
it to −269 degrees Celsius using liquid helium.
Yet despite their best efforts there remains an annoying hissing in the detector, like
the static between channels on an old radio. It seems to be coming from all over the sky.
It is then they spot what must be the culprit. Penzias and Wilson discover pigeons roosting
in the antenna. The heat from their droppings – what they
would later call a “white dielectric material” - must be creating the noise. The pigeons
are carefully trapped and sent to the town of Whippany 30 miles away, only for them to
fly right back. In the end they sadly meet their demise. Penzias and Wilson meticulously
clean out their droppings. But the hissing remains.
In all, Penzias and Wilson spend over a year trying to figure out the source of this maddening
interference. Desperate, Penzias starts phoning round, asking others if they have any idea
what's going on. One day he phones Dicke at Princeton. Dicke is in his office, in the
middle of a meeting about building his device to look for the fireball radiation. As soon
as he hears what Penzias has to say his heart sinks. “Well, boys, we’ve been scooped,”
he says to his colleagues. Penzias and Wilson pick up the 1978 Nobel
Prize in Physics for their serendipity and Dicke is left empty-handed. Gamow would never
win a Nobel either. And so ends the story of the discovery of
the cosmic microwave background. The unmistakable fingerprint of the formation of the first
atoms. Undeniable proof that our universe started with a hot Big Bang.
As the earliest light dispatched into the universe, it is an image of an infant cosmos.
If our present universe were a forty year old human, the cosmic microwave background
is the equivalent of a photograph taken when it was less than ten hours old.
Hidden within it are clues to the universe's future, our present. Small temperature variations
signal the existence of tiny differences in density in the infant universe. The more matter
that falls into these densities, the bigger they get and in turn the more matter that
falls in. Within a few hundred million years the first galaxies will form as matter relentlessly
clumps together. And as well as this, marked across this map of the cosmos, now stretched
to almost 500 million light years in diameter, are the imprints of the sound waves of the
early universe. The remains of the Baryon Acoustic Oscillations.
Experiments such as the Dark Energy Survey, high up in the Chilean Andes, have mapped
the layout of the modern universe like never before. Vast superclusters of galaxies stretch
out among equally gigantic supervoids, which mirror the tiny temperature variations seen
in the Cosmic Microwave Background. The seeds of the universe's structure were sown long
ago. But you don't need a giant horn antenna to
tune into the universe's youth. An old, analogue television set will suffice. In our modern
digital age memories are fading of the snow that would settle across the screen as you
twiddled between channels. One percent of that interference is the cosmic microwave
background. The universe began almost 14 billion years
ago, but the formation of the first atom was such a monumental moment in its history that
echoes of the event remain our invisible companions throughout our lives and will take trillions
of years of expansion yet to be stretched out beyond our view.
And so you may be forgiven for thinking that the rise of the atom was inevitable. That
they are the inescapable fate of a universe made of light and matter, the final destination
of any hot dense soup of particles, as fundamental to reality as their constituent parts.
But that is certainly not the case. In fact, it is quite the opposite.
With the blindfold covering your eyes, your other senses are heightened.
You hear every click and snap as the guns are loaded - all two dozen of them.
You are about to be executed by firing squad. The soldiers raise their weapons and aim the
barrels squarely at your chest.
This is it, you think, and your body braces
for its last breath. Then every single bullet misses.
The Canadian philosopher and author John Leslie asks us to imagine a version of this scenario
in his 1989 book Universes. How unlikely it seems, that you're still alive. It only needed
one shot to hit its target and yet every single shooter missed. You owe your existence to
an incredibly precise and improbable sequence of events. Any deviation from it and you simply
wouldn't be here. The story of our universe – and of its atoms
– is a similar tale. Since its birth 13.8 billion years ago, the universe has gone from
having no atoms at all to being full of more atoms than we could possibly count in trillions
of lifetimes. The atom is so ubiquitous that we take it for granted. Atoms, after all,
are everywhere. And yet the atom is a most ludicrously unlikely
entity. Like your life in that courtyard, it teeters on a tightrope so fine that any
miniscule mis-step would see it snuffed out in an instant. Mess with the physics even
slightly and every trace of chemistry and biology would fade away.
Imagine that you could operate the universe using a giant control panel.
Littered with knobs, dials and switches - each one responsible for some key property of existence.
The masses of certain sub-atomic particles; the strengths of various forces.
In this scenario It wouldn't take much tinkering to destroy atoms entirely and make the journey
of our erstwhile atomonauts impossible. For an atom to be stable, the orbits of its
electrons need to be a lot bigger than the size of the nucleus. Otherwise the electrons
risk crashing down on the atomonauts' homeworld of the proton, like a satellite dragged back
to Earth in fire and fury. You'd only have to make the electromagnetic force a little
bit stronger and electrons would be pulled in tighter.
Weaken it and electrons could fly off on their own like stars flung from out of a distant
galaxy rendering them forever out of our atomonauts' reach. Or you could weaken the strong nuclear
force. Then protons and neutrons wouldn't hug each other so tightly, increasing the
size of the nucleus and hastening the electrons' demise.
A physicist would say that these forces appear 'finely tuned'. The dials have to be in pretty
exact locations otherwise atoms wouldn't exist. And one of the first people to discuss this
so-called fine tuning in detail? None other than Robert Dicke back in 1961.
Electron orbits are far from the only aspects of the atom that appear finely tuned. The
neutron is a mere whisker heavier than the proton, by about one seventh of one per cent.
Physicists know this thanks to increasingly precise experiments - indeed, in 2021 a pair
of researchers from Florida State University measured the deuteron to proton mass ratio
to an accuracy of 4.5 parts in a trillion. The small difference in mass between the neutron
and the proton is greater than the mass of the electron. And this is key. Were the electron
heavier than the difference in mass between its two bulkier cousins, it could be captured
by a proton and turned into a neutron. In other words, you can't change the masses of
electrons, protons or neutrons by much either or again atoms simply wouldn't exist.
Fiddle with the control panel further and you can cause more mayhem. The reason the
neutron is heavier than the proton is due to differences in the masses of their quarks.
As we saw earlier, a proton is made of two up quarks and one down quark. Two downs and
one up form a neutron. The down quark is ever so slightly more massive than the up quark,
so a neutron is heavier than a proton. Yet these masses appear finely tuned, too.
If the difference in mass between down and up quark were larger, the entire history of
the universe would have been radically different. A down quark would be able to decay into an
up quark. If that happened inside a neutron, suddenly the neutron would become a proton.
The deuteron – that key marriage of a proton to a neutron – would be annulled. That means
no fusion after the Big Bang and a universe that only contains atoms of hydrogen. None
of the 117 other types of atom – or elements - in the Periodic Table would exist. No oxygen
for you to breathe or iron to carry that oxygen around your body.
Changing the mass of the quarks isn't the only way to snuff out deuterons. They only
exist because the strong nuclear force can bind a proton to a neutron in the first place.
Make that force just nine per cent weaker and it would be too puny to hold deuterons
together. Going the other way - ratcheting up the strong
force by just two per cent - would have even more profound consequences. It would then
be strong enough to bind two protons together– a form of hydrogen called a diproton. We've
never seen one in the real universe and there have only been tantalising and unconfirmed
reports of one inside experiments such as the Radioactive Isotope Beam Factory in Japan.
Had they existed after the Big Bang, they would have rapidly fused into helium and all
hydrogen would have quickly disappeared from the universe. We'd live in a helium-dominated
universe instead of a hydrogen-dominated one.
And so, whichever dial, switch or knob we
contemplate on the great control panel of the universe, it is surprisingly easy to eradicate
atoms. In other words, all the settings appear to
be in exactly the right place to permit atoms – and the things they are built from - to
exist. It seems quite the coincidence.
It's as baffling and unlikely as your survival in front of the firing squad.
And so physicists and philosophers have put forward three broad ideas to explain this
fine-tuning problem. Maybe it's just dumb luck. After all, the
settings all have to be somewhere and – although almost impossible – they could all have
fallen in the right place so as to give rise to the first atom some 380,000 years after
the Big Bang. By one account the odds are about one in 65 billion trillion. That's roughly
the same odds for you selecting the Sun when asked to choose randomly from a bag containing
all the stars in the observable universe. Many find these odds too extreme to accept
and see this apparent fine-tuning as evidence of someone or something with a steady hand
on the tiller. In other words, it was not an accident but the deliberate act of manually
setting the dials to the right places. This could be some omnipotent deity or a bored
advanced civilisation who wanted to create their own real-life version of The Sims.
There is another option, though. Thanks to strands of evidence like the Cosmic Microwave
Background, cosmologists are confident that the universe began with something like a Big
Bang. But what banged exactly? When trying to answer that question, a tantalising possibility
emerges. The Big Bang is a good theory, but not a perfect
one. Some scientists believe the cracks can be papered over - and the theory salvaged
- if there was more than one Bang. Perhaps an infinity of Bangs, each one giving rise
to a new universe. The settings on the control panel of each universe could vary depending
on the exact way that universe emerged from the cacophony. All possible settings would
be found across this endlessly large multiverse. And which of those universes are you going
to find yourself in? You can't be in ones in which the dials are set so as not to permit
atoms and in turn the stars and planets made from them. You – a giant lump of atoms – can
only find yourself in a universe where the strengths of the fundamental forces and the
masses of the sub-atomic particles allow atoms to form.
And what a journey those unlikely atoms have been on. Their constituent parts forming within
minutes of the Big Bang, to coalesce at recombination, before hurtling across space, spinning into
stars, exploding back into space, pulled into planets, eventually ending up inside a brain
capable of contemplating its place in this vast and intricate universe.
